channel.title: Rate or hate
channel.description:
http://razor.co.il/ben
A little stupid site I made out of boredom a while back I'd like opinions about it.
p.s. you may take and make use of the animation JS freely.

item.title: Rate or hate
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

[quote=“eczema3, post:19, topic:300187”][quote author=Ben link=topic=396466.msg2948596#msg2948596 date=1252353103]
I don’t see the problem with setting the regex as an attribute of an XML element (apart from that I didn’t implement it as a feature within the namespace, but that’s a different topic.)

If someone wishes to change it so that it doesn’t check for email address validity, so be it – the server side script will block it anyway.
The UI features are for the users only, whatever happens when he sends the form for processing is not related to the UI whatsoever.

Look at it this way:
Human <–> Browser <–> Server

The human user is associating with the browser, and the browser is associating with the server.
When the human user attempts to enter an invalid email address, the browser notifies the human user and does not proceed with sending the data, knowing the server won’t accept it.
If the human user wishes to remove this check from the browser, so be it.

When he sends an invalid email address, the server will not accept it and throw him back to the same form he has entered.

This check happens at browser level, and then again at the server level.

Doing this is perfectly OK.
[/quote]
AJAX would be a better option.

When a user changes the field, a request is made and the field/data is updated accordingly.[/quote]
how is it better? that would just result in more queries to the server. you would still need to check if the field is valid on the server side, what if the person has JS disabled? etc

Read full topic

item.title: Rate or hate
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

[quote=“Ben, post:16, topic:300187”]I don’t see the problem with setting the regex as an attribute of an XML element (apart from that I didn’t implement it as a feature within the namespace, but that’s a different topic.)

If someone wishes to change it so that it doesn’t check for email address validity, so be it – the server side script will block it anyway.
The UI features are for the users only, whatever happens when he sends the form for processing is not related to the UI whatsoever.

Look at it this way:
Human <–> Browser <–> Server

The human user is associating with the browser, and the browser is associating with the server.
When the human user attempts to enter an invalid email address, the browser notifies the human user and does not proceed with sending the data, knowing the server won’t accept it.
If the human user wishes to remove this check from the browser, so be it.

When he sends an invalid email address, the server will not accept it and throw him back to the same form he has entered.

This check happens at browser level, and then again at the server level.

Doing this is perfectly OK.[/quote]
AJAX would be a better option.

When a user changes the field, a request is made and the field/data is updated accordingly.

Read full topic

item.title: Rate or hate
item.dc:creator: @Ben Ben
item.description:
@Ben wrote:

I don’t see the problem with setting the regex as an attribute of an XML element (apart from that I didn’t implement it as a feature within the namespace, but that’s a different topic.)

If someone wishes to change it so that it doesn’t check for email address validity, so be it – the server side script will block it anyway.
The UI features are for the users only, whatever happens when he sends the form for processing is not related to the UI whatsoever.

Look at it this way:
Human <–> Browser <–> Server

The human user is associating with the browser, and the browser is associating with the server.
When the human user attempts to enter an invalid email address, the browser notifies the human user and does not proceed with sending the data, knowing the server won’t accept it.
If the human user wishes to remove this check from the browser, so be it.

When he sends an invalid email address, the server will not accept it and throw him back to the same form he has entered.

This check happens at browser level, and then again at the server level.

Doing this is perfectly OK.

Read full topic

item.title: Rate or hate
item.dc:creator: @Uriko Uriko
item.description:
@Uriko wrote:

[quote=“eczema3, post:14, topic:300187”][quote author=Ben link=topic=396466.msg2946912#msg2946912 date=1252263341]
You have not seen the server-side script to determine the level of security of this website (there is none.)
Seeing as there is no server-side script parsing that form anyway, I don’t see how it is a security breach.

This is just a UI feature, ofcourse that if I ever planned on making it work I wouldn’t rely on this.
[/quote]
If it were a working feature and you were using the regex element of that form, it would be a big security flaw.

This is how easy it is:

javascript:document.getElementsByName("email")[0].regex = "some regex goes here";alert(document.getElementsByName("email")[0].regex);

Will set the email element’s regex field to whatever you supply and then give you an alert box showing you the new regex value.[/quote]He knows, don’t worry. Ben would change it if he were to actually implement it into a website.

Read full topic

item.title: Rate or hate
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

[quote=“Ben, post:13, topic:300187”]You have not seen the server-side script to determine the level of security of this website (there is none.)
Seeing as there is no server-side script parsing that form anyway, I don’t see how it is a security breach.

This is just a UI feature, ofcourse that if I ever planned on making it work I wouldn’t rely on this.[/quote]
If it were a working feature and you were using the regex element of that form, it would be a big security flaw.

This is how easy it is:

javascript:document.getElementsByName("email")[0].regex = "some regex goes here";alert(document.getElementsByName("email")[0].regex);

Will set the email element’s regex field to whatever you supply and then give you an alert box showing you the new regex value.

Read full topic

item.title: Rate or hate
item.dc:creator: @Ben Ben
item.description:

You have not seen the server-side script to determine the level of security of this website (there is none.)
Seeing as there is no server-side script parsing that form anyway, I don’t see how it is a security breach.

This is just a UI feature, ofcourse that if I ever planned on making it work I wouldn’t rely on this.

Read full topic

item.title: Rate or hate
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

input type="text" name="email" regex="^((?>[a-zA-Z\d!#$%&'*+\-/=?^_`{|}~]+\x20*|"((?=[\x01-\x7f])[^"\\]|\\[\x01-\x7f])*"\x20*)*(?<angle><))?((?!\.)(?>\.?[a-zA-Z\d!#$%&'*+\-/=?^_`{|}~]+)+|"((?=[\x01-\x7f])[^"\\]|\\[\x01-\x7f])*")@(((?!-)[a-zA-Z\d\-]+(?<!-)\.)+[a-zA-Z]{2,}|\[(((?(?<!\[)\.)(25[0-5]|2[0-4]\d|[01]?\d?\d)){4}|[a-zA-Z\d\-]*[a-zA-Z\d]:((?=[\x01-\x7f])[^\\\[\]]|\\[\x01-\x7f])+)\])(?(angle)>)$" onregexfail="alert ('Bad email address.')" size="20" style="width: auto" />

That’s VERY insecure… someone could easily just change the regex values and you then have yourself a problem.

Read full topic
